title: Corrections: May 23, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 23, 2021.
content: A cover article this weekend about brickyards in the Hudson Valley misstates the years that the Croton Aqueduct was constructed. It was the 1830s and ’40s, not the 1870s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Hail Kevin McCarthy, People Pleaser and Trump Appeaser
description: Kevin McCarthy will do anything to be speaker of the House.
content: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, is frequently derided as a weak, hollow, craven, opportunistic, transactional, nakedly ambitious political animal with no core principles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Phil Mickelson’s P.G.A. Numbers: 50 Years and One More Day
description: Mickelson has a one-shot lead over Brooks Koepka entering the final round of the P.G.A. Championship, where he is bidding to become the oldest man to win a major.
content: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Mindful of keeping his focus as he ages, Phil Mickelson has begun meditating in his spare time. In the third round of the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday, he clearly took his new diversion to the workplace, pausing for long contemplative moments, occasionally with eyes closed, as he prepared to execute a shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio and Tracey Tully
title: 2 Dead and 12 Wounded in House Party Shooting in New Jersey, Police Say
description: The New Jersey State Police responded to reports of a shooting in Fairfield Township late on Saturday night.
content: A New Jersey house party on Saturday that left two people dead and at least a dozen others wounded in a late-night shooting began as a 1990s-themed birthday celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finbarr O'Reilly and Declan Walsh
title: Lava From Erupting Volcano Panics City in Congo
description: After a night of panic and chaos that caused tens of thousands to flee their homes, officials in Goma cautiously declared the emergency over.
content: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo — After a night of chaos and panic, the threat from an erupting volcano to a major city in Congo appeared to recede on Sunday when a river of molten lava halted at the city’s northern edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: Smartly Consider a Bold New Look
description: If you’re feeling the itch to overhaul your hair or finally get that tattoo or nose piercing, the timing makes perfect sense. But pump the brakes before breaking out the scissors or bleach.
content: After spending a year inside her apartment with her two children, Danielle Campoamor, 34, was ready for a new look. The freelance writer and editor in Brooklyn wanted to cut her waist-length dark brown hair to her shoulders and bleach her locks white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: With Cole on the Hill, Yankees Run Scoreless Streak to 30 Innings
description: Pitching has powered a five-game winning streak. The Mets lost in the ninth and Scott Kazmir made it back to the majors with the Giants.
content: Gerrit Cole shook off rare control problems to pitch four-hit ball over seven innings and give the Yankees their most dominant stretch of starting pitching in 89 years, leading his team over the Chicago White Sox, 7-0, Saturday for a five-game winning streak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: A Year After George Floyd: Pressure to Add Police Amid Rising Crime
description: Los Angeles, like other cities across the nation, is facing a rise in gun violence. And the police budget is growing.
content: LOS ANGELES — Helen Jones grew up in Watts in a time of gang wars and a crack epidemic, when the police used battering rams to knock down the walls of suspected drug houses and Black people were routinely profiled or beaten by street cops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: A dry run this weekend of whatever you plan to cook on Memorial Day — maybe Korean beef burgers with sesame-cucumber pickles — is worth the effort.
content: Good morning. We’re just a week out from Memorial Day weekend, our second of the pandemic, and if last year’s celebration was subdued and solitary, this one may see those vaccinated out in the parks in droves, grilling and hugging, playing cornhole, flying kites in the sun. We have loads of recipes for that eventuality. (Also, this helpful 2014 reminder, from The Root, of the essential differences between a cookout and a barbecue.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Belarus Forces Down Plane to Seize Dissident; Europe Sees ‘State Hijacking’
description: The dissident, Roman Protasevich, co-founded a Telegram channel that is a popular opposition outlet in Belarus. The plane was flying from Athens to Lithuania when it was forced down.
content: MOSCOW — The strongman president of Belarus sent a fighter jet to intercept a European airliner traveling through the country’s airspace on Sunday and ordered the plane to land in the capital, Minsk, where a prominent opposition journalist aboard was then seized, provoking international outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Sarah Hughes
title: Gaza, George Floyd, Eurovision: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine
title: Make a Pinwheel to Top a Cupcake
description: These fun cake decorations will create a whirl at your next party.
content: You don’t need to be an expert with a pastry bag to decorate a cake. Make these simple paper pinwheels using the newspaper you’re holding, and poke them into the top of your cake or cupcakes. Newsprint is the perfect lightweight paper to catch a breeze at your outdoor celebration and create some whirly magic. Pinwheels double as entertainment and favors for kids — and grown-ups — as  they run through the party with outstretched arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How Joe Biden Can Win a Nobel Peace Prize
description: The latest Israel-Palestinian conflict could result in a peace deal — if the Americans are willing to broker it.
content: Leon Trotsky once supposedly observed, “You may not be interested in war, but war is interested in you.” To President Biden I’d say today, “You may not be interested in Middle East peacemaking, but Middle East peacemaking is interested in you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
title: As India Stumbles, One State Charts Its Own Covid Course
description: Kerala uses tracking of patients and supplies, a network of health care workers and coronavirus “war rooms” to succeed where the national government has fallen short.
content: When India’s second coronavirus wave slammed the country last month, leaving many cities without enough doctors, nurses, hospital beds or lifesaving oxygen to cope, Sajeev V.B. got the help he needed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Walked Through the Downpour to the Closest Train Station’
description: Rowdy teens waiting for a train, a friendship tested and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Season Finale Looks Back on a Pandemic Year
description: The episode, hosted by Anya Taylor-Joy and featuring the musical guest Lil Nas X, let “S.N.L.” cast members (and the surprise guest Chris Rock) reflect on a challenging season.
content: Just how unusual has the past season of “Saturday Night Live” been? For one thing, it opened its final episode without a traditional sketch and had its performers talk, in comedic but personal terms, about what it had been like to put on the show in the middle of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Neanderthals Were People, Too’
description: Research has shown that they shared many behaviors that we long believed to be uniquely human. Why did science get them so wrong?
content: In the summer of 1856, workers quarrying limestone in a valley outside Düsseldorf, Germany, found an odd looking skull. It was elongated and almost chinless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Assert One’s Ownership
description: Adrienne Atkins makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Ready to bend and stretch and limber up all those creaky parts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran, a Longtime Backer of Hamas, Cheers Attacks on Israel
description: Tehran jumped at the chance to portray militants’ barrages on Israel as revenge for Israeli attacks on Iran. But Israel says Tehran played no role in the latest conflict.
content: The leadership of Iran, engaged in a long shadow war with Israel on land, air and sea, did not try to conceal the pleasure it took in the most recent Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bethany Mollenkof
title: The Faces of Mothers Who Bore the Burden of the Pandemic
description: For a business article on the price that working moms paid, a photographer couldn’t take portraits in person. But shooting them remotely led to a different connection.
content: As a freelance photographer, I was contacted by The New York Times in February to create a series of portraits of 15 mothers in Los Angeles who had been forced out of their jobs because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrienne Gaffney
title: Enjoy the Thrill of Live Theater
description: As productions and festivals reopen this summer, it will be nice to experience some drama outside of our own.
content: As vaccinations and an announcement by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have caused many to reduce their mask use, live performances are slowly returning. While Broadway’s official return is not until September, Radio City Music Hall will reopen on June 19 to host the final night of the Tribeca Film Festival (guests must be vaccinated). And across the New York, venues like the Park Avenue Armory and St. Ann’s Warehouse are already experimenting with socially distanced outdoor performances to resuscitate live theater with caution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Futterman
title: Why Aren’t Races Requiring Vaccination?
description: The Boston Marathon and the New York City Marathon are making triumphant returns this fall. Neither is requiring vaccination for participants.
content: Major marathons are back. Following the moves of the Boston Marathon, the New York City Marathon announced a return to the roads on Nov. 7, with 33,000 runners instead of its usual 50,000-plus, or about 60 percent of its usual size.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: A 1960 Corvette That Vanished for 40 Years After Le Mans Is Auctioned Off
description: Since its chance rediscovery in 2011, the heavily altered racecar has been the subject of seemingly endless legal twists and turns and acrimonious confrontations.
content: The strange, serendipitous, 60-year saga of a historically significant but long-missing 1960 Chevrolet Corvette finally reached a measure of closure on Saturday with its sale for a somewhat disappointing $685,000 “hammer price” at a court-ordered auction in Amelia Island, Fla. A sales commission of about 10 percent made the final “drive-off” price $785,500.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Coronavirus cases and deaths in the United States drop to lowest levels in nearly a year.
description: Experts say the virus is on its way to becoming something we live with in the United States.
content: The United States is adding fewer than 30,000 cases a day for the first time since June of last year, and deaths are as low as they’ve been since last summer. In much of the country, the virus outlook is improving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick
title: So You Want to End the Conversation?
description: So do most people, a recent study found. Plus: amblypigids, a company called Covid, and other staff recommendations in the weekend edition of the Science Times newsletter.
content: With vaccination spreading across the United States, social life has begun to bend toward a semblance of normalcy: dinner parties, restaurants, spontaneous encounters with strangers, friends and colleagues on the street or in the office. It’s exciting but also slightly nerve-racking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Daniel Victor
title: A Teenager’s ‘Hannibal’ Fan Art Will Hang in the U.S. Capitol
description: Representative Andy Kim of New Jersey, who picked the painting to represent his district in the Capitol, did not know it was inspired by a canceled TV show.
content: To the untrained eye, the Cubist artwork painted by Kathleen Palmer, a senior at Shawnee High School in New Jersey, would appear to show two men looking at each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Cable Car Plunges in Italy, Killing at Least 14 People
description: The cable car was traveling at a height of nearly 40 feet, going from the Lake Maggiore area in northern Italy to Mottarone Mountain, when it suddenly fell.
content: A cable car plunged to the ground on Sunday near the top of a mountain in the northwestern region of Piedmont in Italy, killing at least 14 people and seriously injuring a minor, authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: With Loss, Injury-Riddled Mets Finish Road Trip 3-6
description: Cody Poteet looked terrific for the Miami Marlins, retiring the last 14 batters he faced in seven scoreless innings.
content: MIAMI — Cody Poteet figures he has been pitching to keep his job every time out, and the Miami Marlins are happy to keep giving him work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink and Christina Anderson
title: In Sweden’s Far North, a Space Complex Takes Shape
description: The government is turning an old research base above the Arctic Circle into a state-of-the-art satellite launching center. The reindeer will not be happy.
content: KIRUNA, Sweden — The path to the reindeer herder’s spring home took him across four frozen lakes and countless snowy hilltops. Arriving to a light dusting of snow, the herder, Aslak Allas, switched off his snowmobile, and the overwhelming silence of Sweden’s Arctic settled in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A tense peace between Israel and Hamas
content: The end of fighting between Israel and Hamas does little to address the underlying tensions that precipitated the more than 10 days of violence that ended in a cease-fire on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: Eurovision, Celebrating the Sounds of a Postpandemic Continent
description: A dancing finger, chained demons and a victory for Italian rockers. But Eurovision, the largest music contest in the world, is more than just weird.
content: ROTTERDAM — The Italian band Maneskin celebrated its 2021 Eurovision win by the rock ’n’ roll playbook, with bare chests covered in tattoos, champagne spraying and the thuds of fireworks exploding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
title: Yuan Longping, Plant Scientist Who Helped Curb Famine, Dies at 90
description: His development of high-yield rice hybrids in the 1970s led to steeply rising harvests in Asia and Africa and made him a national hero in China, credited with saving countless lives.
content: SHANGHAI — Yuan Longping, a Chinese plant scientist whose breakthroughs in developing high-yield hybrid strains of rice helped to alleviate famine and poverty across much of Asia and Africa, died on Saturday in Changsha, China. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alia Allana
title: Why Is the Virus Killing So Many Pregnant Women in India?
description: The authorities’ decision to block pregnant women from getting the Covid-19 vaccine is having devastating consequences.
content: The doctors at the Government Institute of Medical Sciences, also known as the G.I.M.S., a public hospital in Noida, a suburb of Delhi, recently told me that during the first wave of Covid-19 last year, most pregnant women had moderate symptoms and were able to return home after being hospitalized for a few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: U.S. Grants Temporary Protections to Thousands of Haitians
description: The designation, which will be in place for 18 months, could protect as many as 150,000 Haitians living temporarily in the United States.
content: The Biden administration on Saturday extended special protections to Haitians living temporarily in the United States after being displaced by a devastating 2010 earthquake, reversing efforts by the previous administration to force them to leave the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Daimler’s Truck Unit Maps Plans to Replace Diesel With Hydrogen
description: Electric cars get all the attention, but truckmakers are also under pressure to shift from fossil fuels to electricity.
content: Carmakers have been promising to scrap the internal combustion engine, and now it’s the truckmakers’ turn. But the makers of giant 18-wheelers are taking a different route.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: 21 Runners Dead After Extreme Weather Hits Chinese Ultramarathon
description: The 62-mile mountain race in Gansu Province left athletes in shorts and T-shirts facing freezing rain, hail and high winds.
content: Twenty-one people, including two of China’s top marathon athletes, died after freezing rain and high winds struck a 62-mile mountain race in northwestern China, local officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Joy of Eurovision Fashion
description: For once, entertainers gather and judges bestow awards, but big-brand marketing is conspicuously absent.
content: It is an uncomfortable reality of the modern communal spectacle that more often than not, when it comes to a major award show or performance extravaganza or even sporting event, marketing has overwhelmed personal expression — at least when it comes to the clothes. Red carpets are a big business for public personalities, and fear of looking silly an equally powerful deterrent. Brands have swooped in to exploit that tension to their own ends.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Prices Rise, Biden and Fed See a Rebound
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 23, 2021.
content: “We put the economy in a medically induced coma, and you don’t come out of a coma and run a marathon the next day. We don’t just flip the switch and the economy comes back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘This American Wife’ Review: Wives Out, Knives Out
description: The play is a wild genre-bending parody of, and homage to, “The Real Housewives” franchise.
content: I hate reality TV. It’s not the annoying personalities or the absurd playground-style fights or the drama that belies a fundamental lack of substance. Nope, it’s the assertion that it isn’t another fabricated product but action that’s “real.” It’s even in the name: “The Real World” or “The Real Housewives” — with the implicit assumption that life can be as curated as, say, a filmed brunch gathering of pampered celebrity wives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Four Major Tournaments in Four Months Is a Lot of Important Golf
description: Professional golfers worry about sustaining peak form, but say that scheduling four championships April through July is good for the game, and anyone who gets on a roll.
content: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — This is just the second time in the modern era of men’s professional golf that the sport’s four major championships will be contested in consecutive months, one each from April through July. The schedule was similar in 2019 when, after years of deliberation, the P.G.A. Championship opted to move to May, from its long standing date in mid-August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The U.S. vaccination story varies widely across regions.
description: New England is surging ahead of the national average while the South is lagging behind.
content: Almost half of Americans have received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine. But the U.S. vaccination story varies widely across regions, with New England surging ahead of the national average and much of the South lagging far behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: Yankees Flex Their (Pitching) Muscles in Sweep of White Sox
description: Aaron Judge won the series finale with a walk-off walk, but a dominant stretch by Yankees starters should have opponents alarmed.
content: Jameson Taillon’s peers in the Yankees’ starting rotation set a high bar for him over the past few days. He didn’t quite clear it on Sunday afternoon, but he came close enough for his team to sweep a three-game series with the Chicago White Sox, one of the American League’s best teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: White Troopers Policing Black Bodies
description: The  officers involved in Ronald Greene's death aren't just a few bad apples. It is the whole tree that is shading the truth.
content: Interstate-20 in Louisiana links so many of the places that formed me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: The Nets’ Starters Are Back Together. And So Are the Fans.
description: Over 14,000 fans attended Game 1 of the Nets-Celtics series as Kevin Durant, Kyrie Irving, James Harden, Blake Griffin and Joe Harris started together for the first time this season.
content: Kevin Durant has dazzled in the postseason, having claimed two Most Valuable Player Awards in N.B.A. finals. But before Saturday night, his last postseason appearance was in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: The Mystery of Magic’s Greatest Card Trick
description: At 94, the magician David Berglas says his renowned effect can’t be taught. Is he telling the truth?
content: LONDON — In the late 1940s, the British magician David Berglas started refining a trick that came to be known as “the holy grail of card magic.” To this day, nobody is certain how he did it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 24, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Note: This is our final “What’s Going On in This Picture?” for the 2020-21 school year. The feature will start again in September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Her Book Doesn’t Go Easy on Publishing. Publishers Ate It Up.
description: Zakiya Dalila Harris, a former editorial assistant, is making a splash with “The Other Black Girl,” her debut novel about an African-American woman navigating a nearly all-white workplace.
content: Inspiration struck Zakiya Dalila Harris in Knopf Doubleday’s 13th-floor bathroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: As Talks Bog Down, Hopes for Bipartisan Deals on Biden’s Priorities Dim
description: Democrats and Republicans remain at odds on issues such as infrastructure, policing reform and a commission on the Jan. 6 Capitol assault.
content: WASHINGTON — Negotiations in Congress over some of President Biden’s key priorities are facing new headwinds, dimming Democrats’ hopes that they might be able to overcome the partisan gridlock that has come to define Washington and quickly broker deals with Republicans to push through their ambitious agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola and Sopan Deb
title: Why Being a Knicks Fan Hurts So Good
description: Knicks fans used to disappointment are now reveling in a season of joy. “God forbid, if we win, we are going to burn this city down,” one famous fan said.
content: Ashley Nicole Moss did not have much of a choice when she was growing up. Her father, Jeff, was a Knicks fan, which meant that she was a Knicks fan, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Before Rage Flared, a Push to Make Israel’s Mixed Towns More Jewish
description: An eruption of Arab-Jewish violence inside Israeli cities has focused attention on a movement of religious nationalists seeking to strengthen the Jewish presence in areas with large Arab populations.
content: LOD, Israel — Years before the mixed Arab-Jewish city of Lod erupted in mob violence, a demographic shift had begun to take root: Hundreds of young Jews who support a religious, nationalist movement started to move into a mostly Arab neighborhood with the express aim of strengthening the Israeli city’s Jewish identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Make Japanese Food and Explore Saturn’s Largest Moon
description: This week, watch a performance from the New York City Ballet, take a tour of Lake Titicaca or learn about traditional tea ceremonies.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Michelson
title: Get Wet!
description: This should be the summer you become a swimmer, a paddler or a sailor — it’s easier than you think.
content: Diana Nyad was an elite, competitive swimmer in her youth, growing up in New York City, but it wasn’t until much later in life that she discovered the joys of open-water swimming. “I was doing these marathon swims in my 20s, but I never thought about the ocean,” Ms. Nyad said. “When I got back into swimming in my 60s, I fell head over heels in love with the ocean.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata and Ilana Panich-Linsman
title: These Sisters With Sickle Cell Had Devastating, and Preventable, Strokes
description: Kyra and Kami never got a simple test that could have protected them. Their story exemplifies the failure to care for people with the disease, most of whom are Black.
content: SAN ANTONIO — It was 4 a.m. on a Sunday when Dana Jones heard an ominous sound, barely audible over the whirring of box fans, like someone struggling to breathe. She ran down the hall and found her daughter Kyra, age 12, lying on her back, gasping for air. Terrified, she called 911.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Crypto’s Crashes
description: Bitcoin and other digital currencies fell as much as 20 percent after China effectively banned its financial institutions from providing services related to cryptocurrency transactions.
content: Good morning and happy Sunday. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: It’s the Media’s ‘Mean-Too’ Moment. Stop Yelling and Go to Human Resources.
description: In public radio, there is either an epidemic of bullying or an epidemic of whining, depending on whom you ask.
content: For 20 years, the WNYC radio show “On The Media” has been the sort of place where the hosts’ on-air repartee makes it a fun listen, while their off-air screaming matches send producers diving for cover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Phil Mickelson, at 50, Wins P.G.A. Championship
description: Mickelson became the oldest winner of a major golf tournament after a tense final round on the treacherous Ocean Course at Kiawah Island.
content: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Weathering a riveting, roller-coaster test of nerve over five hours, Phil Mickelson, who will turn 51 next month, won the P.G.A. Championship on Sunday to become the oldest golfer to win a major championship. The record was previously held by Julius Boros, who was 48 when he won the 1968 P.G.A. Championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: After Stumbling to the Finish Line, Liverpool Struts Across It
description: A win at Anfield guaranteed the club a place in the Champions League next season, but only a brief respite before it plunges into soccer’s new reality.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — The goals arrived just as the nerves were fraying and the anxiety mounting, just as the 10,000 fans inside Anfield for the first time in a long time were recalling that watching soccer, live and in the flesh, is not how memory might have made it seem. It is not all celebration and carnival and song. Most of the time, it is nothing but stress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Michael Levenson
title: Yearbook Photos of Girls Were Altered to Hide Their Chests
description: Parents and students said they were outraged that photos of at least 80 female students at Bartram Trail High School in St. Johns County, Fla., had been digitally edited.
content: There had been rumors all day that the yearbook photos had been altered, said Riley O’Keefe, a ninth grader at Bartram Trail High School in St. Johns County, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Lava Recedes After Volcanic Eruption in Congo
description: People returned to areas in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo on Sunday that were threatened by an eruption from Mount Nyiragongo. Thousands had been forced to evacuate nearby neighborhoods overnight.
content: People returned to areas in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo on Sunday that were threatened by an eruption from Mount Nyiragongo. Thousands had been forced to evacuate nearby neighborhoods overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: At Least 14 People Killed After Cable Car Plummets in Italy
description: A cable car plunged from a height of nearly 40 feet as it was traveling from the Lake Maggiore area to Mottarone mountain in northern Italy on Sunday.
content: A cable car plunged from a height of nearly 40 feet as it was traveling from the Lake Maggiore area to Mottarone mountain in northern Italy on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Go Slow on Psychedelics
description: Experts say more scientific research is needed. Also: Aid to Afghanistan after the withdrawal.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coming to Terms With Weight Issues
description: Readers share experiences and some simple rules for weight loss.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
